messages.message:
Anyone else running into a problem where they click on anything in explorer, and instabase logs them out and shows a 404 from the wordpress site?

Update: this is just a bug for organizations that start with `company` or potentially anything that has a corresponding wordpress site slug
Looks like this is specific to a subspace I just created
https://instabase.com/company_training_05_2021
Haha I think we might have an nginx rule that bumps anything that starts with `company` to the wordpress site
yeah.. https://github.com/instabase/instabase/blob/release-21.4.0/webserver/server-nginx/config/nginx-config-template.jinja.yml#L363
cc @Ashish
umm, is that gonna be true for anything that starts with a subdirectory our website… (e.g. cases, careers, contact)….
yup yup it does
Is this resolved? There should be a way to require an exact match for the first part of the url
there are a certain prefixes that are reserved for the marketing site

```/Blog
/Careers
/Company
/Customer
/Discover
/Events
/Webinars
/Customers
/Pricing
/Features
/Resources
/lp
/Marketing
/Community
/Learning
/Platform
/Product
/Products
/What-We-Do
/Partners
/Support
/Transform
/Try
/Use-Cases```
all requests with these prefixes will not make it to the product site
Should we restrict these prefixes in instabase.com (http://instabase.com) for user accounts and spaces? Or should we only block things prefixed with `/company/` with the terminating slash included?

we can do:

1. add / after each of these prefixes however I don't if that will cause a routing problem if someone wants to access instabase.com/company (http://instabase.com/company) [without the slash]
2. add all these prefixes in the blocked list to ensure that no user account or space is created with the prefix
I'd prefer option 1 here assuming there's no seo impact; it's pretty rare that someone would type in a url directly to navigate there, versus navigating there from somewhere else
@Ashish, what if we had two blocks for each prefix, where one is `location = /<name>` and the other one is `location /<name>/`

We must do 2 regardless.

With 1, we just have to make sure `company` and `company/` both work
isn’t blocking all these prefixes from a user space kinda crazy?
well, that's a decision we had made in eng staff when we couldn't come to a conclusion to move entire product under /os prefix
we have to have some tradeoff
like when we get blogger as a customer and they want to try out on instabase.com/blogger-training (http://instabase.com/blogger-training) we’re like sorry?
i thought we meant we couldn’t ship api endpoints like instabase.com/blog/some/path/ (http://instabase.com/blog/some/path/)
not that people can’t make user spaces that start with any of those prefixes
we are testing to check whether we can limit to /blog and /blog/ and not /blogger....
sorry I’m getting a bit carried away. sassy fridays :stuck_out_tongue:
hahaha it's all good
